ocean_uses_covered: Offshore oil and gas, marine transportation, subsistence harvest
lead_institution: Regional Coordination Committee and Beaufort Sea Planning Office
narrative: The Integrated Ocean Management Plan for the Canadian Beaufort Sea, completed in 2009, was designed to facilitate integrated planning and was driven by oil and gas development in the area. However, Fisheries and Oceans Canada has not allocated funds for its implementation.  The Beaufort Sea Partnership continues to meet annually to discuss management activities.

ocean_uses_covered: Commercial fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, military, offshore oil and gas, offshore renewable energy, undersea pipelines and cables
lead_institution: Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Maritime Region)
narrative: In 2013, Canada began developing a Regional Ocean Plan in Nova Scotia focusing on the priority to create marine protected areas.  Previously, the region was host to the Eastern Scotian Shelf Integrated Management Initiative, which was a collaborative, multi-stakeholder planning effort.  The resulting plan, released in 2008, was never approved by Fisheries and Oceans Canada, and implementation stalled.

location: Pacific North Coast of British Columbia
ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, recreation
lead_institution: Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Coastal First Nations, Council of the Haida Nation, North Coast Skeena First Nations Stewardship Society, Province of BC
narrative: Ocean planning of the northern coast of BC is being carried out by the Pacific North Coast Integrated Management Area initiative (PNCIMA) and the Marine Planning Partnership for the North Pacific Coast (MaPP).  When the Canadian government withdrew funding from PNCIMA in 2011, First Nations and the Province of BC formed MaPP. Canada and the Province continued working and released the draft PNCIMA  ocean plan in 2013.

ocean_uses_covered: Cultural activities, fisheries and aquaculture, marine-related forestry, marine transportation, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: West Coast Aquatic
narrative: West Coast Aquatic completed an Integrated Ocean and Coastal Management Strategy in 2012, which was endorsed by all levels of government and ocean stakeholders in 2013.  Action items outlined in the strategy include marine spatial planning, economic development, ocean health, and governance. Ocean plans have been completed for Barkley, Clayoquot, Kyoquot, and Nootka Sounds .

ocean_uses_covered: Cultural activities, fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, offshore oil and gas, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada
narrative: The Placentia Bay/Grand Banks plan reflects Canada's commitment to implement marine protected areas and integrated ocean management.  The success of the plan will depend on commitment of federal and Provincial regulators and stakeholders to incorporate the objectives for the region into management decisions.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, offshore oil and gas, subsistence hunting and trapping
lead_institution: Nunavut Planning Commission
narrative: The Nunavut Planning Commission released the Draft Nunavut Land Use Plan in 2014.  It will guide the use and development of the extensive natural resources, land, and waters under Nunavut's control. The plan designates areas with one of four values, which will be used to guide permitting decisions.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy
lead_institution: Great Lakes Regional Collaboration
narrative: In 2005 the Great Lakes Regional Collaboration released its Strategy to Restore and Protect the Great Lakes. The Collaboration is designated as the Regional Ocean Partnership to lead spatial planning in the Great Lakes, which has not yet begun.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, offshore renewable energy
lead_institution: Gulf of Mexico Alliance
narrative: The Gulf of Mexico Alliance, comprising the five Gulf states and federal agencies, is in charge of the regional effort to develop an ocean plan for US waters in the Gulf.  Efforts are still in the pre-planning phase while the Alliance focuses on other environmental priorities.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, sand mining
lead_institution: Mid-Atlantic Regional Planning Body
narrative: Together with stakeholders from across the region, the Mid-Atlantic Regional Planning Body is developing a Regional Ocean Action Plan to protect ocean ecosystem health and encourage sustainable use. Note: Data development boundaries for the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast Regions used as placeholder until official planning boundaries are available.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, sand mining
lead_institution: Northeast Regional Planning Body
narrative: The Northeast Regional Planning Body, including representatives from New England states, tribes, federal agencies and the New England Fishery Management Council, is overseeing the ocean planning process in New England.  Their efforts are guided by five principles: meaningful public participation, sound science, taking a comprehensive, ecosystem-based approach, good governance, and adaptive management. Connecticut passed a law in 2015 to develop the Long Island Sound Blue Plan. To read the law, visit http://www.cga.ct.gov/2015/BA/2015HB-06839-R01-BA.htm. Note: Data development boundaries for the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast Regions used as placeholder until official planning boundaries are available. The draft plan is now available at http://neoceanplanning.org/plan/

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy
lead_institution: Pacific Islands Regional Planning Body
narrative: The Pacific Islands Regional Planning Body is coordinating the development of a regional plan to achieve balanced, sustainable management of US Pacific islands'  waters. Principles include promoting cultural traditions, values and practices and taking an ecosystem approach to achieving the responsible use of natural resources and long-term economic growth and stability.
shapefile_location: can you use the file - ftp://csc.noaa.gov/pub/Legis-Atlas/FederalGeoregulations/NationalMarineFisheriesServiceRegions.zip - and mask out the parts that cover land to then form the separate regions for the US regional planning bodies?

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, marine transportation, offshore oil and gas
lead_institution: Governors' South Atlantic Aliiance
narrative: In 2009 the governors of N. and S. Carolina, Georgia and Florida established the Governors' South Atlantic Alliance, with the goal of addressing shared coastal and marine challenges and opportunities.  In 2013 the alliance mapped key coastal and ocean ecosystems and the major activities affecting them.  The Alliance was set to initiate an ocean planning process in 2014, but it has not yet begun.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Caribbean Regional Ocean Partnership
narrative: The Caribbean Regional Ocean Partnership was created in 2012 by the Governors of Puerto Rico and U.S. Virgin Islands to improve regional collaboration on ocean management.  The Partnership is carrying out ocean planning to implement ecosystem-based management that accounts for cumulative impacts while promoting resilience and restoration of ocean ecosystems.
shapefile_location: shapefile: http://sero.nmfs.noaa.gov/maps_gis_data/fisheries/caribbean/geodata/caribbean_management_areas.zip     metadata: available at bottom of this page: http://sero.nmfs.noaa.gov/maps_gis_data/fisheries/caribbean/index.html     the layer should represent the federal waters (exclusive of territory waters (or "state" as it's called on this map) and look like this: http://sero.nmfs.noaa.gov/maps_gis_data/fisheries/caribbean/images/island_group_management_areas.pdf

ocean_uses_covered: Marine transportation, offshore oil and gas, offshore renewable energy, tourism
lead_institution: West Coast Regional Planning Body
narrative: Planning on the US West Coast will likely take place at a smaller scale than the entire coast, and the West Coast Regional Planning Body will coordinate the efforts.  The West Coast Governors' Alliance is the regional ocean partnership and is supporting the planning process through the West Coast Ocean Data Portal.
shapefile_location: federal waters off of CA, OR, and WA as delineated by appropriate Fishery Management Region boundaries (ftp://csc.noaa.gov/pub/Legis-Atlas/FederalGeoregulations/NationalMarineFisheriesServiceRegions.zip)

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, marine transportation, tribal rights
lead_institution: Smith River Rancheria
narrative: Eleven tribes in have formed the West Coast Tribal Planning Partnership and are collecting data to develop an ocean plan.  The tribes hope to use the plan to enhance their consultations with government agencies and for engagement in the West Coast Regional Planning Body.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, marine transportation, military, offshore oil and gas, offshore renewable energy, recreation
lead_institution: Florida Department of Environmental Protection and Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission
narrative: Florida's Department of Environmental Protection and Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission has created a web-based tool to aid ocean planning efforts in the state.  The tool builds on efforts by the Florida Oceans & Coastal Council to initiate comprehensive ocean management in state waters.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, education, fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, tourism
lead_institution: National Ocean Service, NOAA, Office of National Marine Sanctuaries
narrative: In 2011, the Sanctuary initiated a review of its marine zones (first established in 1997). The zones are designated with the goal of reducing user conflicts, protecting corals, balancing the needs of the ecosystem. The review is slated to be completed in 2017 and will establish spatial and temporal zones for all areas within the Sanctuary.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, marine transportation, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: State of Hawaii Office of Planning
narrative: Two initiatives in Hawaii are supportive of ocean planning if it emerges.  The Hawaii Coastal Use Mapping Project mapped uses of the nearshore ocean in the Kawaihae-Keсhole area of the Big Island.  Additionally, in 2013, the State updated its Ocean Resources Management Plan to emphasize integrated management.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, tourism
lead_institution: NOAA, Sea Grant
narrative: In 2010, Connecticut's and NY's Sea Grant programs discussed management of ocean planning in the Long Island Sound, which is heavily populated and an important economical and ecological area. In 2014, Connecticut entertained a bill to initiate ocean planning in collaboration with NY. Connecticut passed HB 6839 to develop a Blue Plan for Long Island Sound which took effect on 1 July 2015.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, military, offshore renewable energy, undersea cables
lead_institution: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
narrative: In an effort to plan for offshore wind development, Maryland compiled data about its ocean ecosystems and identified areas most suitable for wind energy projects.  It created an online data portal and mapping tool, the Maryland Coastal Atlas, which continue to be refined.

ocean_uses_covered: Offshore renewable energy, marine transportation, tourism, undersea cables
lead_institution: Massachusetts' Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs
narrative: Massachusetts' Ocean Plan is regulatory and enforceable and covers the siting and performance standards for ocean development.  In 2013, the state initiated its first formal review and update of the plan, which is still underway.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism, undersea pipelines and cables
lead_institution: New York Departments of State and Environmental Conservation
narrative: New York's Department of State is amending its Coastal Management Program to site offshore wind energy and provide greater protection to offshore habitats.  The State is also developing an ten-year Ocean Action Plan to achieve healthy, resilient ocean ecosystems and sustainable economic development.

ocean_uses_covered: Offshore renewable energy
lead_institution: Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development Coastal Division
narrative: Oregon began ocean planning activities in 1991 but has recently focused on establishing marine reserves and siting offshore renewable energy projects.  The state has also conducted analyses of the socio-economic conditions and values of its coastal communities.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy
lead_institution: Rhode Island Coastal Resources Management Council
narrative: In 2010, Rhode Island completed its Ocean Special Area Management Plan to implement ecosystem-based management and to site renewable energy projects in its waters.  This plan also reviewed activities permitted in adjacent federal waters for consistency with its coastal zone management plan.

ocean_uses_covered: Marine transportation
lead_institution: The Maritime Alliance; The Port of San Diego
narrative: In 2013, The Maritime Alliance, an ocean technology industry trade organization, released a study documenting the utility of applying ocean planning to evaluate impacts and manage activities in San Diego's inshore waterways.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, marine transportation, military
lead_institution: Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary; Environmental Defense Center; Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District
narrative: A collaborative effort to address conflicts between shipping vessels and whale activities in the Santa Barbara Channel is in the pre-planning phase.  The effort, which has engaged the Sanctuary and the military, is applying ocean planning tools and approaches to reduce the risk of ship strikes, air pollution, and interference with Navy operations.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, hazard mitigation, offshore renewable energy, sediment management
lead_institution: Texas General Land Office
narrative: Texas is developing a comprehensive ocean plan that is integrative and ecosystem-based with goals that include increasing coordination and efficiencies among state agencies, achieving smarter planning, and identifying critical resource areas.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, fisheries and aquaculture, restoration
lead_institution: Virginia Coastal Zone Management Program
narrative: Virginia's Seaside Special Area Management Plan covers the coastal barrier lagoon system on the Eastern Shore.  The goal is to develop an ocean plan for the area - an important bird, finfish, and shellfish habitat and host to a $50 million clam grow-out industry - by mapping and evaluating uses and recommending guidelines for the allocation of resources.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Washington State Ocean Caucus; Washington Department of Ecology
narrative: In 2010, Washington State passed legislation authorizing ocean planning, and currently the interagency State Ocean Caucus is leading the planning process.  To date, the effort has launched a data portal, conducted analyses of the use of and major industry sectors, and initiated an analysis of coastal economies.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, cultural and heritage uses, marine fisheries economy and aquaculture, marine-related forestry, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Marine Planning Partnership (MaPP) - Council of the Haida Nation and Province of BC
narrative: This plan is founded on an ecosystem-based management framework that focuses on human well-being, ecological integrity and governance and reflects a shared perspective on how to maintain and, where needed, restore a healthy marine environment and a sustainable marine economy on Haida Gwaii. It recommends management measures for uses, activities, and protection of the ocean area.
point_location: hold off on this one - I will accommodate it in the description of the sub-region above

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, cultural and heritage uses, fisheries and aquaculture, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Marine Planning Partnership - North Coast-Skeena First Nations Stewardship Society and Province of BC
narrative: This plan provides recommendations for achieving ecosystem health, social and cultural well-being, and economic development through an ecosystem-based approach to planning and management of coastal waters. It offers detailed direction for the management of the area covered and its uses and for zoning the area for environmental conservation and economic activity.

ocean_uses_covered: Cultural and heritage uses, fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Nanwakolas Council
narrative: Seven First Nations completed individual marine plans with spatial zoning designations to form the basis for their participation in the North Vancouver Island ocean planning process.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Ministry of Sustainable Resource Management, Province of British Columbia (contact now is Ministry of Forests, Lands, and Natural Resource Operations)
narrative: This plan was developed to guide local communities, First Nations and provincial authorities to promote sustainable economic development and manage cumulative impacts by providing direction to marine tenure programs and identify opportunities for development, conservation, and recreation.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Ministry of Sustainable Resource Management, Province of British Columbia (contact now is Ministry of Forests, Lands, and Natural Resource Operations)
narrative: The North Island Straits plan was developed to guide local communities, First Nations and provincial authorities to  promote sustainable economic development and manage cumulative impacts by providing direction to marine tenure programs and identify opportunities for development, conservation, and recreation.

ocean_uses_covered: Fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, marine-related forestry, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Ministry of Sustainable Resource Management, Province of British Columbia (contact now is Ministry of Forests, Lands, and Natural Resource Operations)
narrative: The Quatsino Sound Coastal Plan was released in 2004 to guide the Quatsino First Nation, local communities, and provincial agencies in identifying opportunities for sustainable development, conservation, and recreation and in evaluating applications for coastal land tenure.

ocean_uses_covered: Cultural and heritage uses, fisheries and aquaculture, marine transportation, offshore oil and gas, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Department of Fisheries and Oceans
narrative: Driven by oil and gas development, the Gulf of St. Lawrence integrated management initiative provides for coordination of various governments involved in protecting this productive marine ecosystem.  A draft plan was released in 2012, but Fisheries and Oceans Canada has yet to implement it.

location: Central Coast of British Columbia - MaPP
ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, cultural and heritage uses, marine fisheries economy and aquaculture, marine-related forestry, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Marine Planning Partnership - Province of BC and the Heiltsuk, Kitasoo/Xai'Xais, Nuxalk and Wuikinuxv First Nations
narrative: This planning process is part of the broader First Nations-BC Marine Planning Partnership for the North Pacific Coast (MaPP) initiative and focuses on uses of the intertidal zone and coastal waters, and the lands adjacent to these waters. The overarching purpose of the Central Coast Marine Plan is to identify marine activities that support sustainable communities while protecting and, where appropriate, restoring marine ecosystems.

ocean_uses_covered: Conservation, cultural and heritage uses, marine fisheries economy and aquaculture, marine-related forestry, offshore renewable energy, recreation, tourism
lead_institution: Marine Planning Partnership - Nanwakolas Council and Province of BC
narrative: The overall purpose of the North Vancouver Island Marine Plan is to provide recommendations for achieving ecosystem-based marine management that maintains social and cultural well-being, and economic development based on healthy ecosystems over the long term.

ocean_uses_covered: Aquaculture, offshore oil and gas, offshore renewable energy, sediment management
lead_institution: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control's Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management
narrative: South Carolina assembled an Ocean Planning Work Group to study the utility of ocean planning and guide future work.  The group released a report on ocean planning in 2012 that recommended that the state create an Ocean Action Plan and focus on sustainable development of its ocean space and resources, including wind energy.

ocean_uses_covered: Dredging, offshore renewable energy, sand and gravel mining, undersea cables
lead_institution: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management
narrative: North Carolina is exploring taking ocean planning approach for guiding future activities in its waters, although it is unclear if this effort is progressing.
